Feedback: Please send your thoughts on this publication to   Preface   Our ambitious goal as the Austrian federal government, to achieve climate neutrality for Austria by 2040 and to become a pioneer in climate protection in Europe, requires new approaches, especially in mobility. A trend reversal is needed here in terms of CO2 emissions, because they have increased by 73 percent in traffic since 1990 - instead of falling significantly. This is mainly due to the strong increase in traffic and the continued high dependency of the transport sector on fossil fuels. My department is currently working on the Mobility Master Plan 2030 and helping to develop the federal government's research, technology and innovation strategy (RTI strategy) 2030.   The Mobility Master Plan 2030 is intended to show a concrete path to climate neutrality 2040 in the mobility sector: by means of avoiding and shifting traffic to public transport and active mobility, by increasing energy efficiency and replacing fossil fuels with renewable energy sources. New solutions from the fields of research, technology and innovation will be more important than ever for our climate goals in mobility. It is also important to use the potential of digitization.   The federal government's RTI Strategy 2030 therefore gives high priority to the contribution made by research, technology and innovation to achieving the climate targets.   Mobility policy and RTI policy in the field of mobility are united by the overarching goal of achieving climate neutrality by 2040. I see the RTI mobility strategy with its vision and mission as an essential connecting element between the mobility policy and the innovation policy objectives of my department. With its four mission fields as guiding principles and a broad portfolio of measures, it will enable the implementation of research, technology and innovation policy measures in the area of mobility in the future by involving all relevant stakeholders. I look forward to a good cooperation in order to support our common goal of innovations in and from Austria for a climate-neutral mobility system in Europe in 2040!   Federal Minister Laeonore Gewessler   contents   Preface 3   1 Introduction 6   1.1 Initial situation 7   1.2 Development process 9   2 Target: Vision FTI - Mobility 2040 12   3 Role of the BMK: Mission RTI - Mobility 2040 13   4 Four mission fields as models 14   4.1 Cities: making urban mobility climate-neutral 16   4.2 Regions: mobilising rural areas and connecting them sustainably 18   4.3 Digitization: infrastructure, mobility and logistics services   operate efficiently and in a climate-friendly manner 20   4.4 Technology: developing environmentally friendly transport technologies 22   5 RTI measures 24   5.1 RTI funding 25   5.2   Experimentierr�ume 	 26   5.3 Alliances and implementation partnerships 26   5.4 European and international positioning 28   6 Control concept 29   7 FTI - Mobility Advisory Board 32   7.1 Exercises 33   7.2 Members 33   1   introduction   The Federal Ministry for Climate Protection, Environment, Energy, Mobility, Innovation and Technology (BMK) supports the RTI in order to realise the committed European and national climate goals and to cope with the complex challenges of the mobility system and the related global economic system - Politics with a focus on mobility technological, social and organisational innovations and thus contributes to a sustainable transformation of the mobility sector.   1.1 Initial situation   With the expiry of the national RTI programme Mobility of the Future (2012-2020) and the current EU research framework programme Horizon 2020, the RTI mobility strategy sets the course for the future design of research and innovation policy measures in the area of mobility and supports successful Austrian positioning in mobility-relevant subject areas of the future EU research framework programme Horizon Europe.   Austria has excellent prerequisites for this:   � The Austrian mobility industry is an innovative key sector with high added value, employment and export activity:   - Every ninth job in Austria is anchored in the automotive industry, and the vehicle industry is Austria's second largest export area. The investments in R&D per employee or Employees are at 21,500 euros per person, twice the industry average. 1   - Austria is in an excellent seventh place in the world for exports in the field of \\"rail vehicles and related equipment\\". Austria's share in world trade for rail vehicles is five percent. 2   � Over 30 percent of the total freight transport performance, measured in terms of tonne kilometres, is transported by rail in Austria. Austria is thus at the top of the European Union, and the aim is to maintain and further expand this high share of the railways3. The latest Logistics Performance Index (LPI) of the World Bank from 2018 ranks Austria sensationally in fourth place.   � Thanks to a long tradition of mission-oriented research, technology and innovation funding (RTI funding) in the field of mobility, a diverse network of actors and a broad research base for the transformation of the mobility sector have been created in Austria over the past three decades:   - In the period between 2012 and 2020 alone, approx. 597 RTI projects with approx. 157 million euros funded through various RTI instruments. In addition to classic RTI instruments such as cooperative RTI projects and explorations, the BMK has also supported large-volume lead projects and a cooperative technology initiative on strategic RTI topics, as well as structural instruments such as innovation labouratories in the form of test environments for automated driving, urban mobility labouratories and a transformation labouratory Endowed professorships implemented.   - As part of the COMET programme, support is given to several competence centres that promote joint, multi-year research collabourations between science and industry in the mobility sector.   1 Quelle: investinaustria.at / en / sectors / automotive - industry /.   2 Those: bahnindustrie.at.   3 Source: National Energy and Climate Plan.   � The Austrian track record in the EU research framework programme Horizon 2020 in the mobility-relevant focus \\"Intelligent, environmentally friendly and integrated transport\\" is impressive:   - Of all the individual programmes, this focus is the third most successful and, with around 156 million euros in funding, it is also the third strongest individual programme for Austria.   - Submissions with Austrian participation show a very high success rate of 41 percent (EU average: 32 percent), and Austria also has the relatively highest rate of participations and coordinators, with an above-average proportion of companies.   � Austria offers strategically important research and test infrastructures: In addition to mobility labouratories and test environments for automated driving, unique research infrastructures such as the climatic wind tunnel, the centre on the mountain and the hydraulic engineering labouratory can be found here.   � Since 2020 the BMK has shared responsibility for mobility, innovation and technology as well as climate protection, the environment and energy. This enables the implementation of coherent and coordinated strategies. The Mobility Master Plan 2030 to be drawn up in 2020 is intended to show the concrete path to climate neutrality in the mobility sector by 2040 and, with the new research, technology and innovation strategy (RTI strategy) of the federal government in 2030, the contribution of research, technology and innovation to achieving the Climate goals are emphasised. The RTI mobility strategy acts as a link and concretizes this interface.   � The BMK is (co-) owner of important infrastructure and mobility operators (eg �BB, Asfinag and via donau), agencies in the field of mobility and the environment   (e.g. AustriaTech, SCHIG, Federal Environment Agency), funding agencies or funds (e.g. FFG, aws, climate and energy funds) and non-university research institutions (e.g. AIT).   1.2 Development process   The RTI mobility strategy was created under the leadership of the BMK in the period from November 2019 to August 2020. For this purpose, the BMK has set up a control team headed by Department III / I4 - Mobility and Transport Technologies. This was composed of representatives from the following institutions:   � BMK - Federal Ministry for Climate Protection   � FFG - Austrian Research Promotion Agency,   � AustriaTech - Federal Society for Technological Policy Measures GmbH   �   AIT    -    Austrian   Institute   of   Technology   GmbH   ( Centre   for   Innovation   Systems   &   Policy )   The steering team met eight times, was responsible for designing the content of the strategy and managed the development process and the involvement of stakeholders.   In order to do justice to the various stakeholders in the mobility system with their diverse interests and goals, a broad co-creation approach was chosen for the strategy process:   � In a kick-off event in November 2019 with over 250 participants, national and international experts commented on current developments in mobility, the environment, research, technology and innovation. In three parallel interactive workshops, the participants worked out inputs for the ongoing process of strategy design.   � Building on this, in addition to eight modules / workshops with existing committees / platforms, nine themed workshops were carried out between December 2019 and May 2020. A total of 279 different people could be involved.   Table 1 :   Overview of workshops as part of the RTI mobility strategy   Modules with existing bodies / platforms   Themed workshops   M   1    -    System   Bahn   WS 1 - Target images and narratives   M 2 - National ALICE mirror group   WS 2 - Energy and Mobility   M 3 - Support group mobility labouratories   WS 3 - Digitization and Mobility   M 4 - vehicle technologies   WS   4    -    ( Public )   Operators   M 5 - future of transport infrastructure   WS 5 - Interventionsmix   M 6 - Automated Mobility   WS 6 - RTI - experiments and transfer into practise   M   7    -    ITS   Austria   Plattform   WS 7 - Transnational and European Cooperation   M 8 - Association of the Railway Industry   WS 8 - Health and Mobility   WS 9 - Cooperation at ministry level   FTI - Conference Mobility   25 .    -    26.11.2019   WS 7 - Transnational and European Cooperation   System Bahn Association of the rail industry   National ALICE mirror group accompanying group mobility labouratories   Vehicle technologies   Future of transport infrastructure   � Two public consultations were carried out, one with 988 replies (471 complete replies) and one with 360 replies (229 complete replies).   The result is: a vision of the RTI mobility strategy, the role of the BMK in its implementation (as a mission), four RTI mission fields for transforming the mobility system, four RTI measures and a control concept with which the BMK is implementing will pursue the RTI strategy.   WS   4    -    ( Public )   Operators   WS 5 - Interventionsmix   WS 6 - RTI experiments and transfer into practise   WS 8 - Health and Mobility   WS 2 - Energy and Mobility   WS 1 - Target images and narratives   WS 3 - Digitization and Mobility   WS 9 - Cooperation at ministry level   Automated mobility   ITS   Austria   Plattform   Illustration 1 :   The development process for the RTI strategy mobility   2 target image:   Vision RTI - Mobility 2040   Vision   � Austria has mastered the challenges of change towards a sustainable, climate-neutral and inclusive mobility and transport system in its urban and rural areas.   � Have the Austrian research, technology and innovation players   made a significant contribution to this and to sustainable development, safeguarding the quality of life, competitiveness and employment   played a major role in Austria.   � Innovations from Austria are recognised and in demand worldwide as leading.   3 role of the BMK:   Mission RTI - Mobility 2040   s   d   Mission   We take the necessary research and innovation policy steps to implement a sustainable,   climate-neutral and inclusive mobility system by 2040.   We address relevant technological, structural and organisational developments as well as necessary ones   Changes in behaviour in the economy and society.   We develop instruments and measures that bring about the necessary economic, industrial and mobility-related structural change in   Targeted and effective support for Austria and Europe.   To this end, we shape the coordination and dialogueue between business, science, civil society, politics and administration in a national and international context.   4   Four mission fields as models   With a clear focus on system solutions, the RTI mobility strategy is not structured along individual technology fields or modes of transport, but rather defines four mission fields. These mission fields form the content framework for RTI policy measures as a contribution to achieving climate neutrality by 2040 in accordance with the guiding principle   \\"Avoid - relocate - improve\\"   of Mobilit�tsmasterplans 2030.   The mission fields \\"Cities: making urban mobility climate-neutral\\" and \\"Regions: mobilising rural areas and connecting them sustainably\\" emphasise the spatial dimension with its social and economic relationships, which shape the need for and demand for mobility. Different room types require different solutions and thus a different approach.   The mission fields \\"Digitization: operate infrastructure, mobility and logistics services efficiently and in a climate-friendly manner\\" and \\"Technology: develop environmentally friendly transport technologies\\" focus on two technology-based key areas and address the potential of digitization and other technological developments for a climate-neutral mobility system.   An interlinking of the mission fields of digitization and technology with the two spatial mission fields of cities and regions is to take place via pilot projects and concrete applications in real contexts. Strategic alliances will be established to ensure the necessary coordination between the various actors involved from politics, administration, business, science and civil society and the strategic management of the portfolio of measures in the mission fields.   The four thematic approaches via the mission fields are supported by cross-sectional tasks, the   � promote newly emerging key technologies and significant social and organisational trends with a view to their usability in the mobility context,   � Strengthen Austria's international positioning in the field of RTI and mobility,   � accelerate the coordination and networking of stakeholders and   � Ensure diffusion and impact orientation.   Avoidance, Relocation, Improvement   Figure 2: Mission fields and cross-sectional tasks of the RTI strategy mobility   Quelle :   AIT    -    Austrian   Institute   of   Technology   4.1 Cities: making urban mobility climate-neutral   The overarching goal of this mission field is to make the city more attractive for living and doing business as well as reducing the need for individual and freight traffic with harmful emissions, greenhouse gases and noise in urban areas.   The focus of this mission area is on changes in the volume of mobility and transport and the associated mobility and economic behaviour as well as the provision of the attractive, healthy and inclusive mobility and transport options required for this, which enable individual and goods traffic in the sense of climate-neutral mobility limit.   Research, technology and innovation will create the necessary fundamentals, tools and solutions for the development of active, intermodal and cooperative mobility and transport options and, in the interaction of different disciplines, develop new concepts for the provision and networking of different urban functions.   With regard to the urban structure, the fair division, the design of public spaces and interactions between land use, settlement structure, mobility and transport options as well as information and communication technologies are in focus. In doing so, not only new urban development areas, but above all existing structures are addressed. This should enable short distances for minimal physical mobility as well as attractive mobility and transport options as prerequisites for achieving climate neutrality and support suitable strategies for adapting to the global rise in temperature caused by humans in the urban environment. The context of the surrounding area of the city (city regions) and the associated mobility volume in the area of both passenger and freight transport are also of great importance.   Innovations in the area of infrastructure and means of transport guarantee barrier-free and equal accessibility and usability. New integrated services, business and operator models in urban freight traffic and urban transport logistics, especially with regard to the \\"first / last mile\\", but also the integration of alternative emission-free vehicles and active mobility, are also an integral part of this mission field.   In order for research, technology and innovation to have an impact in this mission field, the embedding of RTI measures in urban / mobility development strategies and the involvement of stakeholders are of central importance. Cross-sectoral solution approaches, incentive systems for behavioural changes and necessary frameworks through innovative policy and planning measures as well as the participation and activation of citizens and the shipping industry should ensure the impact orientation of the mission field.   Figure 3:   Cities: making urban mobility climate-neutral   4.2 Regions: mobilising rural areas and connecting them sustainably   The overarching goal of this mission field is to strengthen and maintain the functionalities of rural areas through innovative combinations of supply structures with new mobility and logistics concepts that contribute to combating the climate crisis, reduce regional disparities and ensure accessibility with minimal energy expenditure in the regional area / Ensure a supraregional context.   The focus is on increasing the attractiveness of rural areas through a climate-friendly improvement in the accessibility and supply of the economy and the citizens as well as an end to the dependence on oil in regional and supra-regional motorised individual and goods traffic in the sense of climate-neutral mobility. Here, too, the perspective goes beyond the mobility system, because issues of provision and access to important supply functions have a major impact on mobility and transport needs.   There is a particular need to develop new solutions for cooperation, coordination and sharing models, but also new solutions for delivery, delivery and collection as well as for the bundling and unbundling of flows of goods. Cooperative, non - commercial on - demand solutions and the integration of new mobility service providers into existing public transport structures also play an important role, for which more flexible legal frameworks are necessary.   In order to contribute to a reduction in motorised individual traffic, questions about increasing the attractiveness of bicycle and pedestrian traffic in the context of spatial planning, the design of traffic routes and, in particular, the relationship between work and mobility, but also tourism must be addressed.   The focus is also on the lack of a mobility infrastructure in rural areas in order to implement new offers. Above all, the topic of the \\"first / last mile\\" is of great importance, especially in rural regions, where the use of automated mobility services and new on - demand services promise solutions Include area.   In order for research, technology and innovation to have an impact in this mission field, an embedding in plans for regional development, the involvement of political decision-makers at the level of the federal states and municipalities as well as the participation of regional companies and citizens are of great importance. Cross-sectoral solutions and the development of new technological, social and organisational innovations in the area of cooperation between companies can also offer opportunities here to make rural areas more attractive.   Figure 4:   Regions: mobilise and sustainably connect rural areas   4.3 Digitization: Operating infrastructure, mobility and logistics services efficiently and in a climate-friendly way   The overriding goal of this mission field is to increase the efficiency, resilience, safety and environmental friendliness of the mobility system. To this end, promising approaches such as Mobility as a Service (MaaS) and Logistics as a Service (LaaS) or automated driving and concepts such as the Physical Internet (PI) should be chequeed for their contribution to these goals and implemented if necessary. The potential of digitization must be harnessed for the development of new services, business and operator models, and environmentally friendly and attractive transport options must be made available to citizens and the shipping industry. Possible rebound effects on the overall system through the optimization of individual logistics chains and mobility options must be taken into account in order to minimise the overall volume of traffic.   The planned RTI measures focus on the provision of the necessary digital, networked infrastructures and international and European coordination in the area of standardisation for the implementation of integrated logistics and mobility chains. Mobility service providers and infrastructure operators should acquire the ability to develop new generic components and systems and to exploit the potential of digitization at an early stage, e.g. B. to optimise transportation or transport capacities or to optimally manage logistics chains, traffic flows, fleets and infrastructures.   On the way there, a large number of RTI needs have to be addressed, which concern aspects such as connected, shared and open data, networked infrastructures and traffic management systems, the security and resilience of these systems or the development of corresponding cooperative services, operators and business models .   In passenger transport, shared, networked information and uniform ticketing for customer acceptance are decisive for the efficient use of different modes of transport. In order to increase the attractiveness of multimodal solutions, it must also be ensured that new private and cooperative offers can be seamlessly integrated into existing public transport systems.   In freight transport, the integration of data and, based on this, the optimization of cross-company processes along the supply chain and in the transport network offer great potential for the increased integration of environmentally friendly modes of transport such as rail or inland waterway and thus for the implementation of sustainable freight transport and transport logistics solutions.   In order for research, technology and innovation to have an impact in this mission field, aspects of data security are of central importance. Due to the increasing networking within Europe, common standards for cross-border mobility and logistics services are also of growing relevance in this mission field.   Figure 5:   Digitization: Operating infrastructure, mobility and logistics services efficiently and in a climate-friendly way   4.4 Technology: developing environmentally friendly transport technologies   The overarching goal of this mission field is the development and broad use of new technologies that make a sustainable contribution to the reduction of CO2 emissions and other pollutants in the overall system and do justice to environmental protection. The area focuses on the technical system and its area of application as a whole (vehicle, infrastructure, development tools, component control, validation technology, traffic dynamics, traffic management, energy optimization, interaction with the environment), with no fossil fuels being used with regard to drive systems should, but exclusively renewable energy sources whose pollutant emissions are close to zero.   The focus is on the further development and diffusion of system solutions, climate-neutral drive systems and resource-efficient and environmentally compatible components for infrastructures (road, rail, artificial and noise protection structures), means of transport (e.g. cable cars, containers) and, in particular, vehicles Production processes required for this (e.g. simulation-based development and testing). Also new system solutions for the coupling of energy supply and   - Storage in the sense of a sustainable, climate-neutral, livable and clean energy future and the subject areas of materials science, lightweight construction and the circular economy system are of central importance in this mission field. Research, technology and innovation in this mission field should also address the subject areas and technology options of electromobility (battery, fuel cell, hydrogen, tank and charging infrastructure, etc.) and questions of energy supply and a holistic approach (sector coupling) with regard to the necessary equipment and take into account the operation of the infrastructures. Therefore, the production, storage and use of renewable or. climate-neutral energy sources in their entyre range a priority of this   Mission field.   In order for research, technology and innovation to have an impact in this mission field - which focuses on technological development - measures must be taken to promote market introduction and penetration. These include B. Testing and implementation in the context of the other mission fields, the promotion of innovation-oriented public procurement (I�B) and increasing the cost truth in the taxeation of mobility. Measures must also be developed at an early stage that reveal the potentially negative effects of the use of these new technologies in the mobility system and can counteract them.   Figure 6: Technology: developing environmentally compatible transport technologies   5   RTI measures   The RTI measures of the BMK should enable the implementation of the four mission fields of the RTI strategy mobility with an integrative consideration of gender and diversity aspects   to advance in all processes.   5.1 RTI funding   The financial support of RTI projects and RTI activities on overarching fundamental issues of sustainable mobility of people and goods in the context of the four mission fields is an important cornerstonnee of the BMK's measures. For this purpose, a portfolio of instruments is available, especially from the FFG, which is used in a demand-oriented manner to achieve the goals of the mission fields, from explorations to cooperative RTI projects and lead projects to innovation labouratories, competence centres and endowed professorships. The RTI funding will be aimed in particular at interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary cooperation networks that are able to create technology development, system and orientation knowledge as well as planning bases and tools and to pilot innovative mobility concepts.   The BMK will further develop RTI funding in the sense of a stronger mission orientation and (co) develop new national, transnational and European funding initiatives that enable new technological foundations and system changes. The key points include:   � Building knowledge and skills for a stronger user, problem-solving and diffusion orientation through greater involvement of operators, local politics and administration as well as representatives of civil society in order to enable the transformation process,   � Development of common target images between RTI actors, users and citizens and problem solving in regional contexts that enable social innovations, business models and the testing of incentives for changes in behaviour,   � Focussing the support of RTI processes in the area of mobility in terms of mission orientation on urgent social issues,   � Development of qualification measures in the education and research system that meet the requirements of the mission fields,   � Support for participation in European and transnational initiatives that enable synergies with global RTI actors and projects,   � Establishment of the necessary long-lasting research infrastructures,   � Mobility workshops for existing and new actors for new ideas,   � Establishing institutional structures for cross-sectoral cooperation and   � Initiation of new funding instruments that are or are possible within the framework of the European aid framework. and in particular support the goal of an impact-oriented RTI policy.   5.2   Experimentierr�ume   Complementary to classic RTI funding, the BMK will establish real labouratory environments in Austrian RTI policy in order to try out and embed research and innovation projects in a real socio-technical context at an early stage. With this, the BMK would like to ensure acceptance among the population and decision-makers and provide new impetus for innovative solutions. For this purpose, the BMK wants to initiate initiatives for the Austrian urban mobility labouratories and mobility transformation labouratories as well as test environments e.g. B. for automated driving, which act as focal points for vital innovation ecosystems in urban and rural regions with the necessary stimulation, transfer and translation processes.   Real-world labouratories should also encourage regulatory experimentation rooms (the term \\"regulatory sandboxes\\" is often used in English), which allow innovative solutions, technologies, products, services and business models to be developed for a certain period of time and in a controlled environment and in a practical manner Temporary exceptions to legal or regulatory provisions that act as obstacles should pave the way for this. In addition, RTI policy is striving for greater cooperation with the legislature in order to anchor innovative approaches more quickly in the regulations .   5.3 Alliances and implementation partnerships   The establishment of transformative solutions in larger regional sub-systems of mobility requires coordination, networking and cooperation on and between several levels of governance and mutual learning4: firstly, at the legislative level, in order to create legal prerequisites for experimentation and, if necessary, learning experiences in new laws to flow in; secondly, at the executive level, in order to be able to offer innovation support across policy fields; third on   4 Source: parlament.gv.at / ZUSD / FTA / 081_reg_experiment.pdf.   Actor level in order to implement innovation processes and to feed back learning experiences into legal processes, but also into economic processes and practises.   In order to enable the necessary coordination and networking, the BMK will create alliances for mobility missions and system change on a strategic level, which will promote the realisation of the mobility mission fields. The \\"Alliances for Mobility Missions\\" will:   � Develop common visions of the future for the mobility mission fields as a guideline for research and innovation,   � Promote co-creation in research and innovation with cities and municipalities, research institutions, industry, users and citizens,   � promote policy coordination with mobility and transport policy, including climate, environment, energy, economy, social issues, health, but also industrial policy,   � Enabling increasing harmonisation of supply and demand-side instruments of RTI policy through synergetic use of the funding instruments of the various agencies and developing accompanying measures for innovation-oriented public procurement,   � Identify regulatory needs, enable learning experiences and anchor them in legal processes and   � Support the participation of Austrian stakeholders in international research collabourations, transnational strategy processes and global value chains that facilitate the development and implementation of   RTI results in the area of mobility serve.   At the operational level, so-called \\"implementation partnerships\\" will be set up to better interlink the various measures. With its RTI policy measures, the BMK will be part of these implementation partnerships   � initiate and coordinate new and established instruments in the field of RTI funding,   � the interlinking of the different funding formats and thus the accelerated handover of RTI projects and initiatives to more implementation-related funding formats or. for synchronisation with demand-side instruments of mobility policy, but also other policy areas through the exchange with the different funding agencies or - funds (e.g. FFG, aws, climate and energy funds) as well as agencies in the field of mobility and the environment (e.g. AustriaTech, SCHIG, Federal Environment Agency) ensure,   � Promote coordination and exchange of information within the framework of participation in European and non-European initiatives, committees, programmes and strategy processes,   � Support the interaction between RTI policy, mobility policy, other relevant policy areas, regional authorities, business, science and civil society,   � Actively manage portfolios within the individual mission fields in order to ensure that the various projects work together over a longer period of time,   � accompanying measures e.g. B. initiate in the areas of qualification and education, regulation, standardisation and procurement and   � enable impact-oriented control, policy learning and thus the ability to adapt to new challenges.   European and international positioning   The central societal challenges in the areas of mobility, transport and industry are being addressed through targeted initiatives by the European Commission, above all with the Green Deal and Horizon Europe. There, too, it is important to integrate RTI policy more closely into an overall policy for solving societal challenges. The BMK will actively work to improve this orientation and, in European and international bodies, pursue the goal of ensuring better coordination between the levels of the EU and the member states. In addition, Austrian companies are given the opportunity to collabourate on research and innovation in the highly globalised mobility industry in order to position them in international value-added networks and to participate in the technological upheaval, as well as to bring added value and jobs to Austria. To this end, the BMK wants to support the successful participation of Austrian actors in the European framework programme for research and innovation (Horizon Europe), in particular participation in the instruments of European RTI cooperation in the mobility-related European partnerships and the missions of Horizon Europe. Participation in non-European research collabourations relevant to Austria, such as B. the IEA (International Energy Agency) and the IPHE (International Partnership for Hydrogen and Fuel Cells in the Economy), will strengthen the BMK within the scope of its possibilities. This also applies to participation in the further development of regulations and standardisations in the transport and mobility context based on scientifically sound results.   6   Control concept   The RTI mobility strategy addresses the necessary system change   in mobility in all its dimensions and is committed to changing the innovation ecosystem, the collabourative networks that connect politics and administration, science, business and civil society. In line with this new claim, the BMK will also set up new structures and processes for the strategic control of the implementation of the RTI mobility strategy as part of the implementation of the RTI mobility strategy.   In view of the ambitious goals of the RTI mobility strategy by 2040, close interlinking with mobility policy, in particular on the basis of the Mobility Master Plan 2030 and RTI policy, in particular the federal RTI strategy 2030, is necessary.   The associated cooperation between politics and administration as well as numerous other actors and stakeholders from science, business and civil society require effective and ongoing coordination of strategic perspectives and operational measures.   Accordingly, in addition to maintaining the strategic coordination of RTI activities with actors from business, science and civil society via established national and European structures, new management approaches at the following three levels are necessary (Figure 7):   � Strategic level: Here is the political coordination between RTI policy and other policy fields and levels, especially in the area of mobility policy, but also with other strategic partners for the mission fields, such as cities, regions, industry and service providers, operators and civil society organisations.   The establishment of so-called \\"alliances for mobility missions\\" has the function of steering on a strategic level. Here, common orientations for the mission fields are defined, the commitment and coordination of the departments and stakeholders involved are ensured, long-term financing perspectives are opened up and the guidelines for set the operational level.   � Operational level: In the development and implementation of measures, an efficient interaction between funding and implementation agencies, regional authorities and other actors is necessary in order to coordinate the activities well in terms of content and timing in the sense of a sustainably financed portfolio. The portfolio can range from funding activities to regulatory adjustments in order to fully address the requirements of the respective mission fields.   Based on international experience, the facility can create so-called   \\"Implementation partnerships\\" contribute to better interlinking the various areas of action. With its measures, the BMK is part of the implementation partnerships, while other departments or cities, for example, carry further measures. agencies and partners to support specific projects, activities and initiatives in the best possible way in line with the goals of the mission fields   It is important to support the various projects (or project portfolios) within the mission fields and to enable exchange and synergy effects. The control of the individual measures that are embedded in the implementation partnerships is central and is ensured by means of appropriate management structures.   � Project level: The measures defined as part of the RTI mobility strategy are ultimately reflected in specific projects in the four mission fields or have an accompanying character for them. The management of these projects will place high demands on project management in view of the wider range of actors, the experimental access and the combination of social, organisational and technological issues. Aspects of open access and open data and the dissemination of results must also be taken into account at the project level.   � Monitoring, dissemination and learning processes are to be provided parallel to the three levels in order to meet the requirements of impact orientation on the one hand and to learn from the first experiences with the new governance architecture for the further development of the RTI strategy on the other. In addition, it is important to ensure strategic support for the mission fields in order to ensure the adaptation of the development path and the RTI strategy over a time horizon of (at least) 20 years. For this purpose, a combination of system monitoring, forecast and a participatory accompanying process with the main stakeholders is planned, which does justice to the open innovation approach.   Mobility policy   RTI - Mobility Policy   FTI - Politics   Quelle :   AIT    -    Austrian   Institute   of   Technology   Figure 7: Governance model of the RTI strategy mobility   7   FTI - Mobility Advisory Board   An advisory board made up of national and international experts was set up to support the implementation and further development of the mobility research, technology and innovation strategy. The members cover the subject of mobility broadly, deal with future issues of mobility and are characterised by visionary thinking. Furthermore, they are   with the mechanisms of the   Innovation ecosystem.   7.1 Tasks   The advisory board meets two to three times a year and supports the BMK in the control, implementation and further development of the RTI strategy mobility through its international experience, he   � thus ensures international connectivity,   � supports you in adapting to new trends and framework conditions and   � supports the identification of the necessary expertise and cooperation partners for the further innovation process.   7.2 Members   Arnd B�tzner   Member of the Board of Directors, Mobility Cooperative   Expertise :   � Urban planning integration of regular services and shared modes   � Suburban and regional mobility   � Paratransit and urban cable cars   Klaus Bonhoff   Head of the Department of Policy Matters, Federal Ministry of Transport and Digital Infrastructure   Expertise :   � Alternative drives and fuels   � Sustainable mobility concepts   � International cooperation   Katja Diehl   Communication and advice, She Drives Mobility   Expertise :   � (Climate) fair mobility   � Inclusion   �   Digitalisation   Florian Lennert   Manageing   Partner ,   Future   Lab   Berlin   Head   of   Mobility ,   NEOM   Expertise :   � Sustainable mobility   � Smart city   �   Systeminnovation   Barbara Lenz   Director, DLR Institute for Transport Research; Professor of Transport Geography, Humboldt University of Berlin   Expertise :   � New mobility concepts   � Automated driving   � Mobility and space   Geraeon Meyer   Head of the European and international business development department VDI / VDE Innovation Technik GmbH   Expertise :   � Vehicle technologies   �   Smart   Systems   Integration   � Transformation of the transport system   Stephan Rammler   Director of the Institute for Futures Studies and Technology Assessment (IZT) and Professor of Transportation Design   Expertise :   � Social and political framework conditions for mobility   � Digitization of mobility   � Urban mobility and local regulation   Sylvia Schwaag - Serger   Professor, Vice President (until December 2020), Lund University   Expertise :   � Internationalisation and an international perspective   � Innovation policy for holistic sustainability and transformative change   � Research, education and innovation policy   Henriette Spyra   Head of Science & Innovation, Federal Environment Agency GmbH   Expertise :   � Transformation processes   � Disruptive targets   �   Effectiveness   Maria Vassilakou   Independent consultant for urban development and management   Expertise :   � Urban mobility strategies   � Integrated mobility systems   �   Walkability   Sylvia V�lker   Sylvia V�lker Consult   Expertise :   � Efficient material and information flows   � Innovative logistics management   � Digitization and supply chain collabouration   \""
